question: When a hybrid car shuts off its gasoline engine at red lights and uses an electric motor, how does this most likely benefit people?

content.source_1: In hybrid cars that shut off the gasoline engine at stops and use an electric motor at low speeds, stop-and-go driving typically burns less gasoline than the same trip in a conventional gasoline-only car.
content.source_2: Burning less gasoline produces fewer combustion-related air pollutants (e.g., NOx, CO, hydrocarbons, particulates), improving urban air quality and public health.
content.source_3: The described vehicle is a plug-in hybrid and is routinely recharged from the local electricity grid.
content.source_4: In regions where most electricity is generated by coal-fired power plants, charging plug-in hybrids leads to higher overall (well-to-wheel) air-pollution emissions per mile than operating efficient gasoline-only cars.
content.source_5: The region where this car is operated relies predominantly on coal-fired power plants for electricity generation.
content.source_6: Well-to-wheel assessments count emissions from both electricity generation and on-road fuel combustion when evaluating a vehicleâ€™s air-pollution impact.
